awd_titl_txt: Mapping Class Groups and Transformation Groups
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is a multi-year research plan to develop new tools for the study of the structure of transformation groups and mapping class groups. The transformation groups such as diffeomorphism groups and homeomorphism groups of a manifold describe all symmetries of the manifold. A manifold is a space that is locally a Euclidean space. The surface of the earth, the surface of a donut and our three or four dimensional universe are all examples of manifolds. The mapping class group is a reduced form of the homeomorphism group of a manifold, in which two transformations are identified if they can be connected by a path of transformations.  These objects have connections with many areas of mathematics, including geometric topology, geometric group theory, dynamics, number theory, quantum field theory, representation theory, and algebraic geometry. This project studies a number of questions about the structure of symmetries of manifolds.  Broader impacts of these efforts include reading groups for graduate students. 

Previously, in a joint work with Kathryn Mann, the principal investigator has proved Ghys' dimension conjecture that given two manifolds M and N, if the homeomorphism group of M has a nontrivial homomorphism to the homeomorphism group of N, then the dimension of M must be less than or equal to the dimension of N. To prove this, an "Orbit Classification Theorem" is developed, which says that every orbit of such a homomorphism is homeomorphic to a cover of some configuration space of M. This finding has a potential to give more results about classifying homomorphisms between transformation groups. Since we have figured out all orbits, now the challenge is to understand how to glue those orbits inside the manifold N.  Another line of work studies the projection map from the transformation group to the mapping class group. In particular, we ask which subgroups of the mapping class group have sections under the projection, where the existence of sections implies that the surface bundle that the subgroup determines will admit a flat structure. In previous work on this subgroup question the principal investigator has proved several results using techniques of "hidden torsion" and rotation number. More tools will be developed specifically to attack this question. Another direction to explore concerns diffeomorphism groups of high dimensional manifolds, specifically, whether there is an example of an infinite torsion group that acts faithfully on some manifold.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
What are the major goals of the project?
The main goals of the project are:
(1) Determine the normal subgroup generated by a bounding pair map
(2) Classify holomorphic maps between configuration spaces of the complex plane
(3) Nielsen realization problem for twits subgroups for 3-manifolds
(4) Mapping class groups of circle bundles over a surface and its realization problems


What was accomplished under these goals and objectives (you must provide information for at least one of the 4 categories below)?
With co-authors Justin Lanier, wrote and submitted a paper "Normal generators of Torelli groups" that studies the normal subgroup generated by a single bounding pair map inside the mapping class group. Johnson proved that a bounding pair map of genus 1 normally generate the Torelli group. However, such result does not hold for other bounding pair. The answer is highly related with Casson invariant for 3-manifolds. This addresses the first major goal of the project.


With co-author Nick Salter, wrote and submitted a paper "Holomorphic maps between configuration spaces." This paper classifies holomorphic maps between pure configuration spaces of the complex plane and the complex line. It also classifies holomorphic maps between the configuration spaces in certain range. This addresses the second major goal of the project.


With co-authors Bena Tshishiku, wrote and published a paper in Israel Journal of Mathematics "Nielsen realization for sphere twists on 3-manifolds," which studies the realization problems for a certain finite subgroup called twist subgroups. The answer is usually not realizable and we give the precise condition when subgroups of the twist subgroup are realizable. This addresses the third major goal.


With co-authors Bena Tshishiku and Alina Beaini, wrote "Mapping class groups of circle bundles over asurface" (published in Michigan Journal of Mathematics) and "Surface mapping class group actions on 3-manifolds". These two papers compute the mapping class groups of circle bundles over surfaces, and also showed that many cases, the mapping class group is not realizable. This is in contrast with the fact that the mapping class group acts on the unit tangent bundle of the surface. The whole program for realization problem is not finished yet. This addresses the fourth major goal and we will work on this project more in the future.

What opportunities for training and professional development has the project provided?
The PI has been involved with the training and mentoring of junior mathematicians. During the reporting period, she has advised 2 undergraduate REU programs. She advised 1 postdoctoral researchers. She also co-organized a conference and served on NSF panel for regular grants. She is on the way to organize another conference for next year.

Have the results been disseminated to communities of interest? If so, please provide details.
The completed papers are available on the PI's web site and the online mathematics archive, arxiv.org.  


What is the impact on the development of human resources?
The PI has been involved in mentoring students, junior researchers, and has helped to establish infrastructure for mentoring such students.

 


Last Modified: 10/16/2024
Modified by: Lei Chen
